It is capable of hydrolyzing various macromolecules, including starch, casein, and Tween 80, and can utilize a range of carbon sources for energy and growth.

The isolation of C. ginsengisoli from ginseng field soil suggests that it may play a role in the soil ecosystem and potentially interact with the ginseng plant. Further research is needed to elucidate the ecological functions and potential applications of this bacterial species.
